update.description:
**Commits**

* Add mono\_camera mesh and .sdf .config files with correct collision and inertia
* Add mono\_camera mesh to urdf file and onto WAM-V
* Integrate sensor post to camera urdf, with height parameter
* Add adjustment link and joint to make the camera frame match base frame
* Simplify all transformations: base->post->arm->camera

This PR is very similar to the **Issue~~#86~~ add 3d lidar mesh** PR. It uses the same sensor post \+ sensor post arm setup, but instead has a camera mesh.

**Images**

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3854322670-Default%20Camera%20Poses.png)
  
_Figure 1: Default camera positions_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1684716592-Close%20up%20Camera.png)
  
_Figure 2: Close up view of cameras_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1148934140-Cameras%20with%20Roll.png)
  
_Figure 3: Cameras with 15 degrees of roll. y="-0.1" x="0.75" R="$\{radians\(15\)\}_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/964520771-Camera%20Inertia.png)
  
_Figure 4: Camera inertia modeled as box_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1221590226-Camera%20Collision.png)
‌

  
_Figure 5: Camera collision modeled as cylinder and box_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3940807887-Camera%20with%20Yaw.png)
  
_Figure 6: 45 degree yaw camera and post. y="-0.45" P="0" Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}" post\_Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}"_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3679749829-Pointing%20Backwards%20Camera.png)
  

_Figure 7: Camera pointing backwards. Chosen camera yaw is independent of post\_Y. y="-0.45" P="0" Y="$\{radians\(-180\)\}" post\_Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}"_
update.title: Issue#85 add monocular camera mesh

content.raw:
Resolved camera seeing itself in [dbe939b](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/dbe939b69a44e68cb52bdc24faf1755b878e2210). Based on the camera mesh, the tip of the lens should be about `0.039`m from the origin. I rounded up to `0.05` to be safe \(in case certain angles make it easy to see itself.

`<clip><near>0.02</near></clip>` =>`<clip><near>0.05</near></clip>`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/2545439929-No_Camera_See_Itself.png)
content.html:
Resolved camera seeing itself in dbe939b. Based on the camera mesh, the tip of the lens should be about 0.039m from the origin. I rounded up to 0.05 to be safe (in case certain angles make it easy to see itself.

<clip><near>0.02</near></clip> =><clip><near>0.05</near></clip>

content.raw:
Resolved material color issue.

In [2d6deb3](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/2d6deb3651f00c42127ab62cf3f1bb9cc712f526), I added the gazebo material tag, but it didn’t work. 

In [48d7669](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/48d76690896a10cdde0f05f914954999ffd23f79), after some investigation, I found out this was the reason why. The visual tag name was causing an issue with parsing.

`<visual name="visual">` => `<visual>`

[https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/132/parser-does-not-handle-urdf-material](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/132/parser-does-not-handle-urdf-material)
content.html:
Resolved material color issue.

In 2d6deb3, I added the gazebo material tag, but it didn’t work.

In 48d7669, after some investigation, I found out this was the reason why. The visual tag name was causing an issue with parsing.

<visual name="visual"> => <visual>

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/132/parser-does-not-handle-urdf-material

You can also check the images in Gazebo directly. Click on `Window` -> `Topic Visualization` , and then, click on one of the camera topics.
content.html:
Up to you, if it’s a lot of code, you can do it in a separate pull request.

You can also check the images in Gazebo directly. Click on Window -> Topic Visualization , and then, click on one of the camera topics.

content.raw:
Yes will do. I will fix the camera sensor issue and then update the lidar macro? Can I do that in the same PR? 

Also, this has been a valuable lesson for me to check the sensors on rviz to make sure they are working as expected when making these PRs. Thank you!
content.html:
Yes will do. I will fix the camera sensor issue and then update the lidar macro? Can I do that in the same PR?

Also, this has been a valuable lesson for me to check the sensors on rviz to make sure they are working as expected when making these PRs. Thank you!

content.raw: If we use this new approach, could you also update the post that’s used in the lidar macro?
content.html: If we use this new approach, could you also update the post that’s used in the lidar macro?

content.raw: Could you also add a new entry to the changelog?
content.html: Could you also add a new entry to the changelog?

content.raw:
\(1\) The color doesn't show up in Gazebo when using `<material>` in that way \(although Rviz should display it properly\). See this related tutorial:

[http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=ros\_urdf#Materials:Usingpropercolorsandtextures](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=ros_urdf#Materials:Usingpropercolorsandtextures)

\(2\) I like the idea!

\(3\) Looks good to me!.

A different issue: Take a look at the image in rviz. It seems that part of the mesh is visualized by the camera. Maybe we need to adjust some parameter in a similar way we did with the laser to avoid self-collision:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/4008978485-rviz_camera.png)
content.html:
(1) The color doesn't show up in Gazebo when using <material> in that way (although Rviz should display it properly). See this related tutorial:

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=ros_urdf#Materials:Usingpropercolorsandtextures

(2) I like the idea!

(3) Looks good to me!.

A different issue: Take a look at the image in rviz. It seems that part of the mesh is visualized by the camera. Maybe we need to adjust some parameter in a similar way we did with the laser to avoid self-collision:

content.raw:
In [f6574c6](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/f6574c657bff3a27790d1d5b728e65ea235f8bb5?at=default), I have scaled the mesh length to be of a more appropriate pole length.

In [3d25599](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/3d255993f515ee56586fe8d698efa89f74ef4d8f), I have labeled variables more explicitly for clarity.

In [8c92025](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/8c9202569a9c90ad5756856beb6a942d0ee89827), I have changed from the pole visual mesh to a cylinder \(simpler\), but for some reason the color is not showing. I tried even making the pole red for a sanity check, but no matter what I do, I can’t see any color other than white. 

Questions

1. Is the color showing up on your computer? 
2. Do you like the idea of switching from a scaled mesh to a simple cylinder shape?
3. Does this pole height look more appropriate? The arm no longer slides up/down the post, but the whole post changes length to match the post.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/102397589-Wrong_color.png)
content.html:
In f6574c6, I have scaled the mesh length to be of a more appropriate pole length.

In 3d25599, I have labeled variables more explicitly for clarity.

In 8c92025, I have changed from the pole visual mesh to a cylinder (simpler), but for some reason the color is not showing. I tried even making the pole red for a sanity check, but no matter what I do, I can’t see any color other than white.

Questions

  1. Is the color showing up on your computer?
  2. Do you like the idea of switching from a scaled mesh to a simple cylinder shape?
  3. Does this pole height look more appropriate? The arm no longer slides up/down the post, but the whole post changes length to match the post.

_Figure 6: 45 degree yaw camera and post. y="-0.45" P="0" Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}" post\_Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}"_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3679749829-Pointing%20Backwards%20Camera.png)
  

_Figure 7: Camera pointing backwards. Chosen camera yaw is independent of post\_Y. y="-0.45" P="0" Y="$\{radians\(-180\)\}" post\_Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}"_

content.raw: Looking at the model, I wonder if we should replace the post with a simple cylinder that has a similar height than the sensor `Z`. That way the posts can look a bit nicer when the sensor is lower. We can still use a black material to look more `stealth` if we want. What do you think?
content.html: Looking at the model, I wonder if we should replace the post with a simple cylinder that has a similar height than the sensor Z. That way the posts can look a bit nicer when the sensor is lower. We can still use a black material to look more stealth if we want. What do you think?

update.description:
**Commits**

* Add mono\_camera mesh and .sdf .config files with correct collision and inertia
* Add mono\_camera mesh to urdf file and onto WAM-V
* Integrate sensor post to camera urdf, with height parameter
* Add adjustment link and joint to make the camera frame match base frame
* Simplify all transformations: base->post->arm->camera

This PR is very similar to the **Issue~~#86~~ add 3d lidar mesh** PR. It uses the same sensor post \+ sensor post arm setup, but instead has a camera mesh.

**Images**

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3854322670-Default%20Camera%20Poses.png)
  
_Figure 1: Default camera positions_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1684716592-Close%20up%20Camera.png)
  
_Figure 2: Close up view of cameras_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1148934140-Cameras%20with%20Roll.png)
  
_Figure 3: Cameras with 15 degrees of roll. y="-0.1" x="0.75" R="$\{radians\(15\)\}_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/964520771-Camera%20Inertia.png)
  
_Figure 4: Camera inertia modeled as box_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1221590226-Camera%20Collision.png)
‌

  
_Figure 5: Camera collision modeled as cylinder and box_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3940807887-Camera%20with%20Yaw.png)
  
_Figure 6: 45 degree yaw camera and post. y="-0.45" P="0" Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}" post\_Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}"_

---

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3679749829-Pointing%20Backwards%20Camera.png)
  

_Figure 7: Camera pointing backwards. Chosen camera yaw is independent of post\_Y. y="-0.45" P="0" Y="$\{radians\(-180\)\}" post\_Y="$\{radians\(-45\)\}"_
update.title: Issue#85 add monocular camera mesh

content.raw:
For `urdf` files in general, is it good to define variables like:

`<xacro:property name="visual_length" value="0.05" />`

I could do this to make some joint and link definitions more clear, but it is not done is most other files so I wanted to ask if this is worthwhile. Eg:

`<xacro:property name="platform_z" value="1.545" />`

And for things like inertia calculations, is it better performance to have them precalculated or should the be calculations like `ixx="${0.83*mass*(width+height)}"` to be more clear?
content.html:
For urdf files in general, is it good to define variables like:

<xacro:property name="visual_length" value="0.05" />

I could do this to make some joint and link definitions more clear, but it is not done is most other files so I wanted to ask if this is worthwhile. Eg:

<xacro:property name="platform_z" value="1.545" />

And for things like inertia calculations, is it better performance to have them precalculated or should the be calculations like ixx="${0.83*mass*(width+height)}" to be more clear?

` 2. `
